questions.prompt: 1. In BG 5.1, Arjuna asks Krishna which is betterâ€”renunciation (sannyasa) of work or performing work in devotion?
questions.feedback: Arjuna asks whether renunciation of work or performance of work is better.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 5.2, Krishna says both sannyasa and yoga of action lead to what?
choices: The same supreme goal of emancipation
questions.feedback: Both renunciation and action lead to the same ultimate goal of emancipation.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 5.3, what is the actual definition of sannyasa (renunciation) according to Krishna?
choices: Renouncing the desire for fruitive results, not the work itself
questions.feedback: Sannyasa means renouncing the fruits of action and desire for results, not abandoning all work.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 5.4, the great sages know the distinction between what two things?
questions.feedback: The learned distinguish between the work of action and the work of renunciation.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 5.5, one who truly understands reaches what state?
choices: Supreme abode by understanding that action and renunciation lead to the same goal
questions.feedback: One who understands the unity of action and renunciation attains eternal peace.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 5.6, is renunciation of action (without devotion) possible to achieve?
choices: No; without yoga it is very difficult to achieve
questions.feedback: Renunciation without devotional service is very difficult to achieve and rarely leads to peace.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 5.7, what is said about one who performs work as a yogi and purifies himself?
choices: He is superior to one who simply renounces
questions.feedback: One who works in yoga and purifies himself is superior to one who merely renounces.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 5.8, what state is achieved by the yogi who has conquered the mind and senses?
questions.feedback: The yogi with conquered mind and senses is always peaceful and in control of himself.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 5.11, the yogi should abandon attachment while what?
choices: Controlling the senses and performing actions
questions.feedback: The yogi should control the senses, abandon attachment, and perform actions through the body.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 5.13, where is the self situated, and what is its relationship to material bodies?
choices: The self is imprisoned in the body
The self is in the heart, transcendental, untouched by the body and its actions
The self is spread throughout the body
questions.feedback: The self dwells in the city of nine gates, untouched by the material body's actions.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 5.15, how does the Supreme Lord treat all beings?
choices: He favors some and punishes others
He does not take the reward or punishment of anyone's actions; ignorance veils the knowledge of the Lord
He judges all equally and punishes severely
questions.feedback: The Supreme Lord is not responsible for actions; ignorance causes people to act and bind themselves to karma.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 5.16, what destroys the illusion of identifying the self with the body and mind?
questions.feedback: The lamp of knowledge illuminates and destroys illusion.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 5.18, a learned person sees all living beings equally because they have what in common?
choices: The same eternal spiritual soul in different bodies
questions.feedback: A learned person sees the same spiritual soul in all beings and does not discriminate.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 5.20, what is the condition of those who have transcended the temporary happiness of senses and material world?
choices: They become ascetic and reject everything
They are not disturbed by pleasant or unpleasant experiences
questions.feedback: Those who transcend the senses and temporary happiness are not disturbed and remain in steady consciousness.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 5.21, where does one established in knowledge and equanimity reside?
questions.feedback: One fixed in knowledge merges with Brahman and enjoys transcendental happiness.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 5.22, what should a yogi avoid according to this verse?
choices: Fleeting happiness from external objects which bring suffering afterward
questions.feedback: A yogi should avoid the temporary and fleeting happiness from external objects.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 5.23, how much control should a yogi have over anger and desire?
choices: Complete control before leaving the body
Control only in the presence of others
questions.feedback: Even before leaving the body, a true yogi must have complete control over anger and desire.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 5.24, where is the yogi's bliss situated?
choices: Within himself; he is absorbed in Brahman consciousness
questions.feedback: The yogi finds bliss within himself, absorbed in Brahman and enjoying transcendental pleasure.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 5.26, in how many days can a yogi establish himself in meditation and transcendental bliss?
choices: Those whose senses are controlled can achieve it gradually through persistent practice
questions.feedback: Perfection in yoga is achieved through persistent practice with controlled senses.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 5.27-28, how should a yogi withdraw the senses from sense objects?
choices: Gradually, while meditating on the Supersoul and fixing the mind on the heart
questions.feedback: The yogi gradually withdraws the senses from sense objects and fixes the mind on the Supersoul.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 5.29, who is the true master and enjoyer of all sacrifices and austerities?
questions.feedback: Krishna alone is the beneficiary of all sacrifices and austerities; He is the sole enjoyer.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 5.29 (continued), what is the result of knowing Krishna as the beneficiary of all sacrifices?
choices: One gains liberation and freedom from fear and lamentation
questions.feedback: Those who know Krishna as the ultimate beneficiary attain liberation and freedom from lamentation.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 5.6 (from purport), what is the difference between Karma Yoga and simple renunciation?
choices: Renunciation leads to liberation but Karma Yoga does not
Karma Yoga includes detachment from results; renunciation without yoga is difficult
Renunciation is superior in all ways
questions.feedback: Karma Yoga combines action with detachment; simple renunciation without yoga practice is difficult.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 5.11 (from purport), why does the yogi perform actions despite their being futile to the senses?
choices: Out of duty and devotion to the Lord
questions.feedback: The yogi performs actions as duty to the Lord while remaining detached from results.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 5.12 (summary), what is the path to liberation described in Chapter 5?
choices: Performing prescribed duties without attachment and with devotion to the Lord
questions.feedback: Chapter 5 teaches that performing one's duty in devotion and without attachment leads to liberation.
